summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel to Judge Alison J. Nathan, responding to the government's complaint about public statements. The letter argues that the government and accusers' counsel have engaged in extensive prejudicial publicity without reprimand, creating a double standard, and defends statements made by David Oscar Markus, who is not counsel of record in the case.

persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case S2 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), accused of crimes related to Jeffrey Epstein. Her defense counsel is writing this letter on her behalf.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her.

events.title: Maxwell's Arrest Press Conference
events.description: Acting U.S. Attorney held a press conference after Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest, which the defense alleges was a deliberate violation of Rule 23.1, villainizing Maxwell and giving credibility to accusers.

events.title: Court's Warning on Public Statements
events.description: The court issued an order warning counsel and agents about violations of rules regarding public statements.

events.title: Court's Order on Media Statements
events.description: The court issued an order (Dkt. 312) regarding public statements, prompting this response letter from Maxwell's defense.

keyFacts: Maxwell's defense counsel claims they have scrupulously complied with Local Criminal Rule 23.1 regarding media silence, unlike the government and accusers' counsel.
The defense argues a double standard exists, where the government's press conference after Maxwell's arrest and public statements by accusers' counsel (like David Boies) have gone without reprimand.
The statements in question were made by David Oscar Markus in a New York Daily News Op-Ed, and he is not counsel of record in the case.
The letter asserts that Maxwell faces a 'tsunami of adverse publicity' daily, which could impact the jury pool.
The defense cites legal precedent (Gentile v. State Bar of Nevada) that efforts to persuade the public a defendant should not be prosecuted are permissible.
